Legal_Issue: Whether the Immigration Appeal Division violated principles of natural justice and procedural fairness by not allowing the Minister to make submissions
Legal_Rule: Administrative bodies must respect natural justice, ensuring both parties have the opportunity to present their case, including receiving evidence and making arguments
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness (implied by context of procedural fairness)
Procedural_Issue: Failure to allow the Minister's representative to make submissions before decision was rendered
Grounds_for_Claim: Violation of procedural fairness and natural justice
Outcome_on_Merits: Not reached; case remitted for rehearing
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: The IAD violated procedural fairness by failing to permit submissions from the Minister after indicating it would do so
Legal_Framework: Principles of natural justice, procedural fairness in administrative decision-making
Applicant_Challenge: Minister challenged the IAD's failure to allow submissions
Court_Result: Federal Court allowed the application and ordered a rehearing by a differently constituted IAD panel
Legal_Rule_Source: Common law principles of natural justice, statutory framework of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Remedy_Requested: Quashing of the IAD decision and order for a new hearing
Remedy_Sought: Rehearing before a differently constituted IAD panel
Resolution_Mechanism: Judicial review followed by remittal for rehearing
Legal_Provision_Cited: Principles of natural justice, procedural fairness under IRPA
Applicable_Process: Administrative appeal process before IAD, followed by judicial review in Federal Court
Governing_Rule: Natural justice requires that all parties be given a fair opportunity to present their case
